column1:
P1021111 EF88 Austeyr - Weapon Qualification
P021608 EF88 (Tier 3) Ancillaries Operatior Basic (215457)
P100318 Sight Unit Day, Dual Range 5.56MM F2 Elcan Specter Dr 1-4X Enhanced Day Sight (213911)
column2: FMS-DFW-A-FOU - Operate and apply fire with the service rifle
column3: 1. Complete the EF88 Weapon Qualification Test successfully
2. Complete the Weapon Qualification Shoot
3. Conduct the F2 Elcan Specter Test
4. Explain the layout and procedures of a military range
5. Identify types and natures of service rifle ammunition
6. Apply service rifle weapon saftey requirements to the weapon and ammunition
7. Handle the service rifle safely
8. Adopt the degrees of weapon readiness
9. Strip and assemble the service rifle correctly
10. Adopt the appropriate firing position to suit the conditions
11. Carry out immediate action and stoppage drills as required.
12. Comply with range safety brief and practice brief when firing on the range
13. Apply effective fire using the in-service rifle
14. Demonstrate the combat shooting behaviours consistently when operating the in-service rifle
15. Clean, maintain, function test and secure the service rifle and ammunition
16. Comply with Rules of Engagement and Orders for opening fire consistently
17. Comply with fire control orders
18. Conduct a rifle practice grouping
19. Conduct a rifle practice zeroing
20. Conduct a close shooting rifle practice
21. Conduct Rifle Practice 1-3
22. Conduct Rifle Practice 3A Combatant Assessment
23. Conduct an Administrative Top Up during the rifle practices
24. Use cover appropriately during the rifle practices
25. Demonstrate safe and appropriate trigger preparation throughout the rifle practices
26. Maintain safety throughout rifle practices
27. Conduct the post-engagement sequence during rifle practices
28. Conduct a tactical reload during rifle practices
29. Conduct an emergency reload during the rifle practices

column1:
P129036 Army Initial Foundation Training (AIFT) Module A 218611
P129037 Army Initial Foundation Training (AIFT) Module B (218612)
P129038 Army Initial Foundation Training (AIFt) Module C (218613)

2. Conduct effective weapon and equipment setup
3. Demonstrate safe weapon direction and handling

5. Apply static threat engagement stances and grip at the Engagement Position and Weapon Stance

3. Handle the LSW safely
4. Adopt the degrees of weapon readiness
5. Strip and assemble the LSW correctly
6. Carry out immediate action and stoppage drills as required for the LSW
7. Utilise the buddy system for safe weapon handling

column1: P1021301 Foundation Communications Course (214094)
column2: FMS-ES-A-FOU - Operate the in-service radio
column3: 1. Describe communications security procedures
2. Describe cryptographic security procedures
3. Describe the employment of the combat net radios and BMS
4. Describe WHS radiation hazard considerations for combat net radios
5. Establish communications utilising a pre-configured in-service communications device
6. Conduct the procedure for calling and answering accurately
7. Demonstrate the different types of calls
8. Conduct the procedure for arranging a voice conversation
9. Conduct the procedure for using nicknames and designators
10. Conduct the procedure for transmission of messages
11. Conduct the procedure for corrections and repetitions
12. Record all transmissions in the signals log book
13. Operate the in-service radio without a breach in WHS, COMSEC or damage to the equipment
14. Demonstrate foundation combat communications behaviours

column1: P1026906 Binocular Night Vision Device (BNVD) (215757)
column2: FMS-ES-B-FOU - Operate the Binocular Night Vision Device (BNVD)
column3: 1. Explain the effective maintenance requirement for the BNVD
2. Explain if any modifications can be applied to the BNVD or helmet mount
3. Setup the CWBP and BNVD power source
4. Fit and secure the helmet mount onto the helmet
5. Fit and secure the BNVD onto the helmet
6. Turn the BNVD on
7. Adjust anterpapillary adjustment as required
8. Adjust for correct eye relief
9. Adjust the brightness
10. Adjust the focus to suit individual requirements
11. Set the auto sleep function on temporary
12. Place the BNVD into the sowed position
13. Turn off the BNVD
14. Remove the BNVD from the helmet mount
15. Complete a live fire zero practice with an IR aiming device whilst viewing through the BNVD

column1: P106870 L3 Laid (Laser Aiming & Illumination Device) (215697)
column2: FMS-ES-C-FOU - Operate the L3 Laser Aiming and Illumination Device (LAID)
column3: 1. Conduct safety precautions for the LAID
2. Fit and remove the LAID to the weapon securely and without damage to the device or weapon
3. Explain high and low power
4. Explain the maintenance of the LAID
5. Explain a likely fault and actions required to rectify the fault
6. Explain and demonstrate dry zeroing
7. Explain the live fire zero procedure
8. Correctly operate the LAID
9. Explain Laser Safety
10. Explain Weapon Light Safety
11. Complete the live fire zero practice with LAID whilst viewing through the BNVD

column1: P106002 L3 LAIRD (Laser Aimining Illumination and Ranging Device) (215696)
column2: FMS-ES-F-FOU - Operate L3 Laser Aiming Illumination and Range Device (LAIRD)
column3: 1. Conduct safety precautions for the LAIRD
2. Fit and remove the LAIRD to the weapon securely and without damange to the device or weapon
3. Explain high and low power
4. Explain the effective maintenance of the LAIRD
5. Explain a likely fault and actions required to rectify the fault
6. Explain and demonstrate dry zeroing
7. Explain the live fire zero procedure
8. Correctly operate the LAIRD
9. Explain Laser Safety
10. Explain Weapon Light Safety
11. Complete the live fire zero practice with LAIRD whilst viewing through the BNVD

column1: P1010982 F1/F3 Grenade - Weapon Qualification

2. Safely handle F1 Fragmentation Grenades

5. Adopt throwing positions as required
6. Apply the throwing principles
7. Safely throw at least two F3 Practice grenades
8. Safely throw two F1 Grenades
9. Refurbish F3 Practice Grenades

column1: P102281 Army First Aid Certification

2. Treat a fracture of either an upper or lower limb
3. Manage truama injuries effectively
4. Apply a PIT correctly
5. Treat environmental illnesses
6. Treat burns effectively
7. Treat for shock
8. Apply all precautions required for moving a casualty with a suspected spinal injury

column1:
P109054 CBRN Basic Operator (205340)
P127560 In-Service Tier 1 Chemical Detector (Light Chemical Detector 3.3)
P127561 In-Service Tier 1 Radiological Detector (DMC 3000)
column2: FMS-FC-B-FOU - Survive in a CBRN Threat Environment
column3: 1. Describe the history of Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear (CBRN) warfare
2. Describe CBRN agents, their characteristics and effects on human, animal and plant life and the environment
3. Describe operations in CBRN threat environments and defensive countermeasures
4. Describe CBRND doctrine and unit SOPs
4. Use current in-Service Tier 1 CBRN detection equipment appropriately
5. Report CBRN threats accurately
6. Demonstrate knowledge of current in-Service CBRND Individual Protective Ensemble (IPE).
7. Carry out CBRND Immediate Action (IA) and Immediate Decontamination (ID) Drills.
8. Carry out IPE cleaning and maintenance.

column1:
P129036 Army Initial Foundation Training (AIFT) Module A 218611
P129037 Army Initial Foundation Training (AIFT) Module B (218612)
P129038 Army Initial Foundation Training (AIFt) Module C (218613)
column2: FMS-FC-C-FOU - Apply principles of field craft in the field environment
column3: 1. Judge distances accurately
2. Observe the battlefield by day and night
3. Identify and indicate targets
4. Assemble, adjust, wear and maintain field equipment & PPE
5. Live in the field maintaining operational discipline
6. Maintain a high standard of individual health and hygiene in the field
7. Recognise why things are seen
8. Apply and maintain individual camouflage and countersurveillance measures for personal protection
9. Employ field signals effectively
10. Apply individual movement techniques
11. Explain the guidelines for good concealment
12. Demonstrate the principles of personal camouflage
13. Prepare and consume meals from CR1Ms
14. Dispose of rubbish accordingly
15. Interpret and relay field signals
16. Prepare and sleep in a sleeping area
17. Apply the principles of observation by night effectively
18. Demonstrate effective movements for moving at night
19. Conduct morning, afternoon, evening and defensive routines

column1: P102277 ACS (PTE) AS Navigation
column2: FMS-FC-D-FOU - Conduct basic navigation
column3: 1. Plot and measure grid bearings within 20mils
2. Calculate magnetic variation from the map
3. Plot a six figure Grid Reference with a protractor
4. Measure a distance on the map (within 100m accuracy)
5. Convert grid bearings to magnetic bearings and magnetic bearings to grid bearings
6. Determine distance by foot over varying terrain in patrol order
7. Relate identifiable features on a map to corresponding ones on the ground
8. Orientate a map using a compass
9. Shoot a magnetic bearing to visible objects
10. Maintain a bearing while on the move.
11. Conduct three legs of navigation by day
12. Conduct one leg of navigation by night
13. Demonstrate a change in bearing by conducting two legs of navigation consecutively
14. Navigate a minimum of 100m per leg
15. Plot and measure distance on a map within 100m accuracy

column1: P109594 Australian Tactical Combat Casualty Care - All Combatants
column2: FMS-BC-A-FOU - Provide care under fire or threat
column3: 1. Suppress the enemy threat (conduct basic drill)
2. Direct or move a casualty to safety within the tactical setting
3. Identify the principles and clinical interventions associated with the management of combat casualties during care under fire
4. Determine the requirement and apply the in-service tourniquet

column1: P109594 Australian Tactical Combat Casualty Care - All Combatants
column2: FMS-BC-B-FOU - Provide Tactical Field Care
column3: 1. Incorporate security setting into treatment
2. Identify the principles and clinical interventions associated with the management of combat casualties during Tactical Field Care
3. Identify and address Catastrophic Haemorrhage
4. Identify compromised Airway and need for interventions
5. Identify Breathing status, and need for interventions
6. Assess Circulation and address other haemorrhage
7. Assess Disability
8. Prepare casualty for Environment and Evacuation

column1: P109594 Australian Tactical Combat Casualty Care - All Combatants
column2: FMS-BC-C-FOU - Provide Tactical Evacuation Care
column3: 1. Maintain security perimeter in accordance with unit tactical operating procedures
2. Discuss triage principles appropriate to the management of combat casualties during Tactical Evacuation
3. Describe the fundamental principles involved in packaging, transporting and handling of a casualty
4. Assessment and treatment as per tactical field care
5. Discuss various evacuation platforms available in an Area of Operations
6. Structure of a 9 liner CASEVAC request
7. Complete a PM377-1 Tactical Combat Casualty Care card
8. Send a MIST and use ATMIST as a handover to a clinician including the assessment of a casualty's pulse and respirations
9. Explain medical care rendered when placed aboard evacuation platforms
10. Discuss considerations for an evacuation route

column1: P109685 Army Combative Program Level One All Corps (216118)
column2: FMS-BC-D-FOU - Apply the principles of the Army Combatives Program Level 1
column3: 1. Describe the Army Combative Program and its evolution within the Australian Army context.
2. Understand the use of force continuum in the Army Combative Program.
3. Correctly employ the principles of the Army Combative Program.
4. Demonstrate an understanding of the kinetic stance, kinetic phase and kinetic IA
5. Correctly employ counter to strike techniques.
6. Employ ground survival techniques whilst engaging a simulated enemy combatant.
7. Correctly execute primary weapon retention.
8. Correctly employ first responder - emergency assist actions.

column1:
P129036 Army Initial Foundation Training (AIFT) Module A 218611
P129037 Army Initial Foundation Training (AIFT) Module B (218612)

column2: FMS-BC-E-FOU - Apply the principles of Battle Craft in the field environment
